content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student is studying the properties of <math alttext="C a S O 4" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CaSO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math alttext="P b S O 4" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PbSO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>. The student has samples of both compounds, which are white powders. (a) The student tests the electrical conductivity of each solid and observes that neither solid conducts electricity. Describe the structures of the solids that account for their inability to conduct electricity.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student is studying the properties of <math alttext="C a S O 4" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CaSO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math alttext="P b S O 4" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PbSO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>. The student has samples of both compounds, which are white powders. (a) The student tests the electrical conductivity of each solid and observes that neither solid conducts electricity. Describe the structures of the solids that account for their inability to conduct electricity.

The student places excess <math alttext="C a S O 4, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>S</mi><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mi>s</mi></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in a beaker containing <math alttext="100 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>m</mi><mi>L</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> of water and places excess <math alttext="P b S O 4, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>P</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>S</mi><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo></mstyle><mi>s</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mo>)</mo></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in another beaker containing <math alttext="100 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>m</mi><mi>L</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> of water. The student stirs the contents of the beakers and then measures the electrical conductivity of the solution in each beaker. The student observes that the conductivity of the solution in the beaker containing the <math alttext="C a S O 4, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>S</mi><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo></mstyle><mi>s</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mo>)</mo></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>is higher than the conductivity of the solution in the beaker containing the <math alttext="P b S O 4, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>P</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>S</mi><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo></mstyle><mi>s</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mo>)</mo></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.(b) Which compound is more soluble in water, <math alttext="C a S O 4, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>S</mi><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo></mstyle><mi>s</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mo>)</mo></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="P b S O 4, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PbSO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> ? Justify your answer based on the results of the conductivity test.

The left side of the diagram below shows a particulate representation of the contents of the beaker containing the <math alttext="C a S O 4, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>S</mi><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo></mstyle><mi>s</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mo>)</mo></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> from the solution conductivity experiment. (c) Draw a particulate representation of <math alttext="P b S O 4, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>P</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>S</mi><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mo>(</mo></mstyle><mi>s</mi><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mo>)</mo></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and the ions dissolved in the solution in the beaker on the right in the diagram. Draw the particles to look like those shown to the right of the beaker. Draw an appropriate number of dissolved ions relative to the number of dissolved ions in the beaker on the left.

(d) The student attempts to increase the solubility of <math alttext="C a S O 4, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> by adding <math alttext="10.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="2 molar H 2 S O 4, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext></mtext><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to the beaker, and observes that additional precipitate forms in the beaker. Explain this observation.

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
